paper_metadata.title: Effectiveness of a disability-inclusive graduation programme on health outcomes among ultra-poor people with disabilities in Uganda: a cluster-randomised controlled trial

program_information.program_name_citation: This study evaluated the effectiveness of a disability-inclusive graduation (DIG) programme on health outcomes among ultra-poor people with disabilities in Uganda
program_information.country_citation: We conducted a two-arm, parallel cluster-randomized controlled trial in four districts of Northern Uganda
program_information.target_population_citation: This study evaluated the effectiveness of a disability-inclusive graduation (DIG) programme on health outcomes among ultra-poor people with disabilities in Uganda

component_a_cash_support.cash_evidence_citation: Households in treatment clusters received up to 18 months DIG intervention between December 2020 and June 2022, combining asset transfers, cash support, skills training, financial inclusion activities, and disability-specific services including rehabilitation and assistive devices

component_b_assets.assets_evidence_citation: Households in treatment clusters received up to 18 months DIG intervention between December 2020 and June 2022, combining asset transfers, cash support, skills training, financial inclusion activities, and disability-specific services including rehabilitation and assistive devices

study_characteristics.outcomes_evidence_citation: The primary outcome was experience of illness/injury in the past 3 months, assessed at both first follow-up (immediately post-intervention) and second follow-up (about 16 months post-intervention), with secondary outcomes including unmet health needs, mental health status, unmet assistive product needs, and healthcare expenditure
study_characteristics.design_evidence_citation: We conducted a two-arm, parallel cluster-randomized controlled trial in four districts of Northern Uganda
